div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: C ODE-DIVISION multiple-access (CDMA) implemented with direct-sequence spread-spectrum (DS/SS) is among the most promising multiplexing technologies for wireless telecommunications services. The explosive growth in wireless telephony, in conjunction with emerging new applications, has inspired a significant recent interest in advanced signal processing techniques for enhancing the performance of nonorthogonal signaling schemes for such multiple-access communications systems. These techniques generally fall under the category of multiuser detection [20], which refers to optimum or near-optimum demodulation of data in such situations. It has been demonstrated that multiuser detection provides very substantial performance gains over detection techniques conventionally used in multiple-access channels. Considerable recent research in this area has focused on the development of adaptive techniques for multiuser detection Manuscript received April 14, 1997;revised March 27, 1998. Adaptivity not only allows multiuser detection to be applied without additional protocol overhead with respect to that required by conventional methods, but it also allows multiuser detectors to operate in the dynamic environment found in mobile communications applications. More recently, blind techniques for adapting linear multiuser detectors have been proposed in [8] and [22]. These blind techniques essentially allow one to use a linear multiuser detector for a given user with no knowledge beyond that required for implementation of the conventional matched filter for that user. The blind technique in [8] for adapting the linear MMSE detector is based on a constrained minimization of the output energy (MOE) of a linear filter, using either the least mean-square (LMS) algorithm or the recursive leastsquares (RLS) algorithm. It has been shown that under either adaptation algorithm, this blind technique suffers from a saturation effect in the steady state, which causes a significant gap between its steady-state performance and the performance of the true linear MMSE detector [8], [16]. Moreover, if the background ambient noise level is low, the signal covariance matrix is almost rank deficient, and the RLS method may fail to provide satisfactory results.

In CDMA systems, the effective rank of the noise-free signal covariance matrix is usually less or much less than the signal dimension or the filter length . Therefore, the useful information in the signal can be projected without loss onto a signal subspace of rank . Motivated by this observation, a blind adaptive multiuser detection technique based on subspace tracking is developed in [22]. This technique remedies the problems that stem from the RLS version of MOE method. In addition, by using low-complexity adaptive subspace tracking algorithms, considerable complexity reduction can be achieved when the rank of the signal subspace is much smaller than the signal dimension .

In many CDMA communications applications, such as cellular mobile radio systems, indoor wireless communications, and underwater local area networks, the channels exhibit severe multipath fading, which limits the system performance. In this paper, we extend the work in [22] and develop a blind multiuser detection theory for multipath channels based on rank revealing processing and subspace tracking. The receiver structure considered here bears the same spirit of the RAKE receiver [17], that is, first, the signal of interest along each path is collected, and the interference (multiple-access interference and multipath interference) on that path is mitigated; then, the signals collected from all paths are optimally combined to yield the decision statistic on the received data symbol. Two key issues are addressed, namely, blind adaptive interference suppression and blind adaptive channel estimation.

The receiver considered in this paper employs a bank of linear filters (decorrelating filters or linear MMSE filters) at the front end for interference suppression. It is shown that through the use of signal subspace estimation, both the decorrelating (i.e., zero-forcing) filterbank and the linear MMSE filterbank can be obtained blindly, i.e., they can be estimated from the received data with the prior knowledge of only the signature waveform of the user of interest. Two forms of subspacebased linear filterbanks are developed, and their equivalence in terms of interference suppression capability is established. These subspace-based blind adaptive interference suppression techniques require, at each symbol epoch, the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a signal subspace. This can be achieved using computationally efficient sequential adaptive eigendecomposition (subspace tracking) algorithms. The focus of this paper, however, is on the development and performance analysis of the subspace-based interference suppression methods in multipath channels, assuming the signal subspace components are available. Nevertheless, in the numerical simulation section, some examples are provided to demonstrate the performance of subspace-based blind adaptive multiuser detection methods, using a particular subspace tracking algorithm found in the recent literature.

We also develop a blind adaptive technique for estimating the channel state for diversity combining. It is shown that the channel state vector is related to the principal eigenvector of the covariance matrix of a linearly transformed filterbank output. A recursive-least-squares (RLS) type of algorithm is then derived for blind channel state estimation. This algorithm also produces the post-combining decision statistic as a byproduct.

This paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we introduce the signal model and the diversity receiver structure considered in this paper. In Section III, we discuss the concept of signal subspace and the techniques for adaptive signal subspace tracking. In Section IV, we derive two forms of subspace-based linear filterbanks for interference suppression in multipath channels and show their performance equivalence. In Section V, we develop a blind adaptive method for channel state estimation. In Section VI, we provide some simulation examples to demonstrate the performance of the blind adaptive algorithms proposed in this paper. Section VII contains the conclusions.

Two issues in this context will be addressed, namely, blind adaptive interference suppression and blind adaptive channel state estimation.

Recently, MUSIC-type methods have been proposed for channel estimation in multipath CDMA systems [1], [12]. These methods essentially estimate the effective signature waveforms in the multipath channels. The estimated effective signature waveforms are then used in multiuser detection. A limitation of such approaches is that the estimated effective waveforms may not be unique, and thus, there could be a discrepancy between the estimated waveforms and the true effective waveforms. Moreover, these are batch estimation methods and are computationally expensive, which makes it difficult to apply these techniques to real-time wireless communications applications.

div.head: B. Signal Subspace Tracking
div.p: The linear multipath filterbanks for interference suppression that will be derived in the following sections are expressed in terms of the subspace components and . These subspace components can be estimated from the received signal . The classic approach to subspace estimation is through batch eigenvalue decomposition (EVD) of the sample covariance matrix or batch singular value decomposition (SVD) of the data matrix, which are computationally too expensive for adaptive applications. Considerable research in signal processing has been focused on the development of computationally efficient adaptive subspace tracking algorithms, i.e., sequential algorithms that compute at each time step an exact or approximate EVD or SVD of the signal covariance matrix. An early survey of the existing techniques in this area is given in [4]. More recent results are found in [2], [3], [5], [18], [19], and [24]. The computational complexities of these subspace tracking algorithms vary among or operations every update, where is the input vector dimension, and is the number of desired eigencomponents. Note that the recently developed fast subspace tracking algorithms with complexity , e.g., [3], [19], and [24], when applied to the blind adaptive multiuser detection application, can achieve a considerable complexity reduction compared with the RLS version of the MOE method for blind multiuser detection [8], if the rank of the signal subspace is much less than the signal dimension [22]. It is beyond the scope of this paper to compare the performance of these subspace tracking algorithms. Rather, the focus of this paper is on the development and performance analysis of the subspace-based blind multiuser detection in multipath channels, assuming the signal subspace components are known. For the simulation examples provided in Section V, the subspace tracking algorithm (PASTd) found in [24] is employed for signal subspace tracking.

However, as discussed in Section I, the RLS method may fail to provide satisfactory results when the sample covariance matrix is ill-conditioned, which may happen frequently in realtime applications. Remark 2: It is seen from Propositions 2 and 3 that both the decorrelating filterbank and the linear MMSE filterbank can be expressed in terms of the signal subspace components and and the signature of the user of interest. Since the signal subspace components can be estimated adaptively from the received signal using various subspace tracking algorithms, we say these filterbanks for interference suppression can be implemented blindly, i.e., with the prior knowledge of only the signature of the user of interest.

Notice from Propositions 2 and 3 that the computation of the decorrelating filterbank and the linear MMSE filterbank based on the signal subspace components is somewhat involved. In the next section, we develop an alternative yet equivalent implementation of the subspace-based linear filterbanks for interference suppression in multipath channels. In this approach, parallel subspace trackers are employed, each tracking the signal subspace of a remodulated received signal. The th linear filter can then be written directly in terms of the signal subspace components obtained by the th tracker, with little extra computation.

div.head: VI. NUMERICAL EXAMPLES
div.p: In this section, we present some simulation examples to illustrate the performance of the proposed blind adaptive method for joint interference suppression and channel estimation in multipath CDMA channels.

Example 1-Probability of Error in Multipath Rayleigh Fading Channels: The primary performance measure for any receiver is its probability of detection error. In this example, the error probabilities of three receivers are compared, namely, the conventional RAKE receiver, the diversity receiver with a decorrelating filterbank at the front end, and the diversity receiver with a linear MMSE filterbank at the front end. The simulated system is a synchronous CDMA systems with six active users . The processing gain is . The signature sequence of the desired user is a sequence, whereas the signature sequence of other users are randomly chosen. The number of resolvable paths is . The channel is assumed to be subject to Rayleigh fading, i.e., the channel fading gains are complex Gaussian random variables. It is assumed further that the receivers have perfect knowledge of all users' signatures and the channel states of all paths, such that both the decorrelating filterbank and the linear MMSE filterbank can be explicitly constructed. div.head: VII. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we have developed a blind adaptive technique for demodulating a user's signal in multipath CDMA channels. This technique is based on signal subspace estimation. The receiver that we have considered bears the same structure as the RAKE receiver, that is, first, the useful signal along each path is collected, and the interference on that path is mitigated; then, the signals collected from all paths are optimally combined to yield the decision on the received data symbol. We have addressed two issues, namely, blind adaptive interference suppression and blind adaptive channel estimation.

Vincent Poor, Fellow, IEEE Abstract-A blind adaptive technique for signal demodulation in multipath code-division multiple-access (CDMA) communication channels is proposed. This technique is based on signal subspace estimation. The receiver employs a bank of linear filters (decorrelating filters or linear MMSE filters) at the front end to mitigate the multiple-access interference and the multipath interference. A channel estimator is used to estimate the channel state for diversity combining. It is shown that through the use of signal subspace estimation, both the decorrelating filterbank and the linear MMSE filterbank can be obtained blindly, i.e., they can be estimated from the received signal with the prior knowledge of only the signature waveform of the desired user. Two forms of the subspace-based linear filterbanks are developed, and their equivalence in terms of the interference suppression capability is established. These subspace-based blind adaptive interference suppression techniques require, at each symbol epoch, the eigenvalues and the eigenvectors of an appropriate signal subspace, which can be obtained using computationally efficient sequential adaptive eigendecomposition (subspace tracking) algorithms. Moreover, a blind adaptive method for estimating the channel state is developed, which also produces the postcombining decision statistic as a byproduct. Index Terms-Blind adaptation, CDMA, channel estimation, diversity combining, interference suppression, multipath channels, signal subspace tracking.

The receiver employs a bank of linear filters (decorrelating filters or linear MMSE filters) at the front end for interference suppression. We have developed two forms of the subspace-based linear filterbanks and have shown their equivalence in terms of interference suppression performance. These subspace-based blind adaptive interference suppression techniques require, at each time step, the eigenvalues and the eigenvectors of a signal subspace, which can be obtained using computationally efficient sequential adaptive eigendecomposition (subspace tracking) algorithms. We have also developed a blind adaptive technique for estimating the channel state for diversity combining. This algorithm produces the post-combining statistic as a byproduct. Finally, we have provided numerical examples to demonstrate the performance of the proposed blind adaptive multiuser receiver in multipath channels.
